awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Intelligence Tool for Analysis of Legal Documents
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to establish an artificial intelligence (AI) system capable of providing data-driven insights for attorneys. The legal community currently lacks data analysis tools to help with civil case preparation, which can lead to suboptimal trial outcomes. The proposed technology can help lower costs through document analysis. The technology is designed to both automate and improve the decision-making process and enable attorneys to expand their case load, as well as enabling cost-effective representation.  

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will use federated learning techniques to train the technology’s algorithm across multiple decentralized databases without exchanging data samples, thus keeping information private and confidential. This approach overcomes the lack of access problem in applying AI to legal cases, without compromising data confidentiality. The proposed research will include two major objectives: 1) improve and verify the accuracy of the platform, and 2) create internal checks to ensure that the model does not propagate bias. Computational outputs will be assessed using data and records from randomly selected cases with known outcomes to demonstrate system accuracy; moreover, the model will explicitly account for potential sources of bias.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project undertaken by Claudius Legal Intelligence was aimed at transforming the legal industry through an advanced artificial intelligence (AI) system. This system was developed to provide data-driven insights for attorneys, addressing the existing challenge in the legal community of a lack of efficient data analysis tools for civil case preparation. Traditionally, the process had been bespoke and time-consuming, often leading to suboptimal outcomes. The Claudius team's innovation lies in developing AI technology that significantly reduces the costs associated with document analysis, streamlining and enhancing the decision-making processes for attorneys. This breakthrough enables attorneys to handle a larger caseload and offer more cost-effective representation, directly impacting legal accessibility and justice. A notable feature of the Claudius project is the use of federated learning techniques. This approach allowed the Claudius team to train their algorithm across multiple decentralized databases without exchanging data samples, effectively maintaining data confidentiality and privacy. This method addressed the challenge of limited data access in the legal sector while ensuring data confidentiality. The project's research was centered around two primary objectives: 1) improve and verify the accuracy of the platform, and 2) create internal checks to ensure that the model does not propagate bias. The Claudius team rigorously assessed the computational outputs against data and records from randomly selected cases with known outcomes, demonstrating the system's accuracy. Moreover, the model was specifically designed to account for and mitigate potential sources of bias, ensuring fair and unbiased decision-making in legal assessments. In conclusion, the Claudius platform marks a significant advancement in legal technology. By automating and improving the decision-making process, it empowers personal injury attorneys to serve their clients more effectively and manage an increased number of cases. This technology not only enhances access to justice but also equips attorneys with tools to make data-driven, impartial decisions, setting a new standard in the legal industry. The successful completion of this SBIR Phase I project by the Claudius team opens the door for broader applications and continuous enhancements in the field of legal AI technologies.


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Vinicius Silvestrin Pantoja
